ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Trigeminal Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by imaging and pathology; symptoms included facial numbness (Vth nerve) and auditory signs due to brainstem compression.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Common CPA tumor causing retrocochlear signs, though facial numbness typically appears later than in this case.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Meningioma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Another common CPA/posterior fossa tumor that can cause mass effect symptoms.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity in the presence of tinnitus and hyperacusis.
To evaluate speech recognition and check for rollover, a sign of retrocochlear pathology.
To assess the acoustic reflex arc; absence or decay can indicate retrocochlear involvement.
Neurodiagnostic evaluation to assess auditory nerve and brainstem integrity.
Imaging to visualize the suspected retrocochlear mass lesion.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry revealed normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally, but retrocochlear signs were prominent: significant rollover in the right ear, elevated or absent acoustic reflexes on the right, and abnormal ABR morphology (large Wave I, small Wave V) with an abnormal ILD. A CT scan confirmed a large mass arising from the Trigeminal nerve compressing the brainstem.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Thresholds essentially normal bilaterally (0-15 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent recognition at 30 dB SL, but the right ear showed 'rollover' at high intensities.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Contralateral reflexes elevated or absent for the right ear; borderline abnormal for the left ear.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Large Wave I (0.8 µV), small Wave IV-V (0.17 µV), extended I-III latency. Left ear: Normal. Abnormal ILD for Wave V (0.6 msec).

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.result_summary: Mass lesion (approx 4 cm) at lateral aspect of pons extending into CPA, arising from Trigeminal (Vth) nerve.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Four months post-surgery, hearing sensitivity remained normal. Retrocochlear signs resolved: rollover was absent, acoustic reflexes returned in the right ear, and ABR Wave V amplitude increased markedly, normalizing the I/V ratio. Tinnitus persisted, but hyperacusis had resolved.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent scores with no 'roll-over' for either ear.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Reflexes now present in the right ear; left ear reflexes obtained at lower levels than pre-op.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear Wave I decreased in amplitude and Wave V increased markedly compared to pre-op; latencies showed little change.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: At the 5-year research follow-up, pure tone data were unchanged. ABR testing demonstrated significant neural recovery, with Wave V latency decreasing by 0.6 msec compared to the 4-month post-op check, suggesting brain plasticity.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear Wave V latency decreased by 0.6 msec compared to 4-month post-op check.

proposed_items: Long-term follow-up to assess neural recovery
counseling_actions: Explain that auditory symptoms (rollover, processing issues) were caused by tumor compression of the auditory nerve and brainstem.
Discuss the 'rollover' phenomenon where clarity worsens at higher volumes due to neural compression.
Highlight the positive surgical outcome: preservation of hearing sensitivity and recovery of neural function (reflexes returned, ABR improved).
Address persistent tinnitus, noting that while the tumor is removed, ringing may persist due to prior nerve stress or central changes.

red_flags_present: Asymmetric auditory findings (rollover, absent reflexes, ABR abnormalities)

escalation.rationale_short: Large mass lesion compressing the brainstem and cranial nerves requires surgical intervention.

follow_up_plan.objective: Research follow-up to monitor long-term neural recovery and plasticity.

expected_outcome: Pure tone data were unchanged (normal thresholds).
ABR Wave V latency decreased 0.6 msec compared to 4-month post-op check, suggesting brain plasticity.
Patient still had bilateral tinnitus, but otherwise had completely recovered.
